title: Who ... ?
header: Who claimed that indigenous peoples are inherently different?

value.text:
Introduction

Throughout history, the tendency to perceive people as different has been prevalent. This often led to the creation of artificial hierarchies, where certain groups were deemed inferior. But what rationale lies behind these actions? Did European settlers consider Indigenous peoples inferior?

Differentiation in Eurasia history

This study focuses on the inhabitants of the Iberian Peninsula before their arrival in the Abya Yala (Porto-Gonçalves, Carlos Walter, pp. 39-43)/America, excluding the brief Viking presence (Sanders, Ralph, , 7,8), as they did not establish long-term settlements in the Abya Yala/América, and were likely deterred by Indigenous peoples (McGhee, Robert, ).

The Greco-Roman civilization commonly referred to those beyond their borders as "barbarian", this is a generic word that "tends to transform the neighbors of the Roman Empire into a collectivity" (Walter, Goffart, , pp. 277-278) and it is also a word that excludes people, like Suzanne Devallet cites (Devallet, Suzanne). This notion persisted through subsequent centuries and was not unique to interactions involving Iberian peoples.

xclusionary attitudes can also be traced in Arab sources, such as the works of Ibn Khaldūn's work (Rosenthal, Franz, ). In his descriptions of the Negro people of Lamlam, he recounts instances of invasion and enslavement (Rosenthal, Franz, , pp. 118-119), as well as mentions of other Homo sapiens groups residing further south:

  • "Beyond them to the south, there is no civilization in the proper sense. There are only humans that are closer to dumb animals than to rational beings. They live in thickets and caves and eat herbs and unprepared grain. They frequently eat each other. They cannot be considered human beings."

While both groups of people are recognized as human, an artificial division is created, positioning one as a "rational" group and the other as akin to "irrational animals".

Despite almost a millennium passing between the fall of the Roman Empire and Ibn Khaldūn's work, parallels can be drawn between the Roman tendency to distance themselves from barbarians (Devallet, Suzanne, , pp. 112) and the Arab perception of differentiation between Sub-Saharan peoples and regions influenced by Arab culture (Rosenthal, Franz, , pp. 119).

The notion of differentiation has been ingrained in Eurasian societies for centuries, evident in their treatment of neighboring peoples. Therefore, it is unsurprising that such attitudes persisted when encountering the unfamiliar.

Encounters with the the unknown

Documentation reveals widespread mistreatment of Indigenous peoples across the entire Abya Yala/America continent by colonizers. However, this discussion will focus on two accounts preserved by Franciscans in Yucatán, Mexico, and Jesuits in the former Captaincy of São Vicente, Brazil.

The colonizers' behavior in Yucatán, where Diego de Landa stood out, are described by different research. Among the well-documented atrocities, it is possible to list:

  • Torture (Timmer, David E., , pp. 477-478).
  • Destruction of ancient Mayan texts (Timmer, David E., , pp. 479-480), including burning them (Segrest, Colt, , pp. 32-36).

The reasons behind these atrocities are multifaceted. David E. Timmer suggests that colonizers' actions stemmed from an apocalyptic worldview, as outlined in his research (Timmer, David E., , pp. 485-488). Conversely, Colt Segrets attributes such acts to the Christian perspective of idolatry, citing Diego Muñoz Camargo's letter, which equates Indigenous peoples to irrational animals: "hay indios tan simples y de tan poco entendimiento, que se pueden comparar con animales irracionales" (Segrest, Colt, , pp. 44). This perspective echoes Ibn Khaldūn (Devallet, Suzanne, , pp. 118-119).

In the ancient Captaincy of São Vicente, Portuguese colonizers also displayed a sense of superiority. Although not explicitly stated, Saint José de Anchieta's description of Tibiriçá as possessing qualities beyond those of a typical Brazilian exemplifies this mindset: "tanta madureza que não parecia homem do Brasil." (Anchieta, José de, Santo, , pp. 187). Such notions of superiority likely justified the massacre of Indigenous groups like the Confederation of Tamoios (Perrone-Moisés, Beatriz, and Sztutman, Renato, ). We are not going to detail these Indigenous, because the people are already described in the genealogical section (History Tracers, , Indígenas de São Vicente).

For further insights into the complex dynamics of colonization, Ailton Krenak's work is recommended for study (Krenak, Ailton, , pp. 7-16).

Desire for European identity

The belief in superiority persisted in Brazil, leading prominent researchers Pedro de A. T. Paes Leme and Luiz G. Silva Leme to inaccurately attribute their Indigenous ancestors' origins to Europe (Schneider, Alberto L., , pp. 99-100). This inclination is exemplified by their attempt to relocate their ancestors' birthplace. The ASBRAP has hosted a discussion on Paulista women's DNA (History Tracers, , Living Beings), providing valuable insights. One individual, Isabel Velho, was erroneously identified as being from Porto, Portugal, by Pedro de A. Taques Paes Leme (Paes Leme, Pedro T. de A., , Tomo III, pp. 141). However, subsequent DNA analysis of her descendant indicates Indigenous heritage (de Sillos, Luiz Gustavo, , t. 02:12:26).

And what is the Indigenous perspective?

While it cannot be definitively stated that Indigenous cultures never exhibited notions of superiority, the destruction of ancient texts and the absence of a written language in some Indigenous societies make it challenging to ascertain. However, it is known that conflicts, such as those in Mesoamerica, existed among Indigenous groups, although they differed in nature from Eurasian conflicts (Chase, Arlen F., Chase, Diane Z., ).

Is it possible tofin a equality understanding?

xamining Indigenous cosmovision offers insight into the concept of equality among all beings. The Mayan sacred text, the Popol-Vuh, details the creation of Homo sapiens (Vela, Enrique, ), including a narrative involving "wood man" and monkeys (Popol Vuh, , pp. 39 ; Popol Vuh, , Ch. 3, pp. 8), suggesting a shared origin:

  • "“Señal de esta gente son los monos que ahora andan por los montes y por eso quedaron de señal, porque solo fueron de palo, hechos por el Criador, y el mono por eso se parece al hombre porque es señal de otro género de hombres hechos de palo"

  • And it is said that their descendants are the monkeys which now live in the forests; these are all that remain of them because their flesh was made only of wood by the Creator and the Maker. And therefore the monkey looks like man, and is an example of a generation of men which were created and made but were only wooden figures.

This idea of our species and other animals being part of the same creation process reflects a fundamental equality among all beings.

Centuries later, during his journey through Abya Yala/América in his the route (Darwin, Charles, 19--, Vol. I, pp. 57), Charles Darwin documented his observations in nature. He articulated the concept of equality among all Homo sapiens tracing their lineage back to a common ancestor. Contrary to common misconceptions, this ancestor was not a monkey but another species that underwent mutations before evolving into Homo sapiens (Darwin, Charles, 19--, Vol. I ; Darwin, Charles, 19--, Vol. II). It was not added specific citations for the last sentence, because there is the understanding hat people should study the whole Charles Darwin's work.

While both the Maya people and Charles Darwin arrived at conclusions about equality, their perspectives and methodologies differed. Nevertheless, their observations underscore a shared understanding of the interconnectedness and equality of all living beings.

Conclusion

Throughout history, notions of superiority have been used to justify domination, whether through claims of being a "a different society" (Devallet, Suzanne, , pp. 112), or simplifying conquests (Corrêa, Fernanda M., , pp. 80,81). Despite advancements, such as the debunking of race as a biological concept, but this is not a consensus, like Rose M. Brewer shows in her work (Brewer, R.,). The structural racism persists, hindering progress and perpetuating inequality (de Almeida, Silvio Luiz, ). The cycle of superiority and inferiority persists into the 21st century (Urzedo, Danilo, and Pratichi Chatterjee, ), evident in ongoing attempts to exploit Indigenous peoples and territories. As we confront this reality, it's essential to reflect on our own beliefs and behaviors:

  • Do we struggle to accept that everyone is inherently equal, despite differences in preferences?
  • What drives our desire for superiority over others?
  • Why do we cling to our own perspectives as the only valid ones?
  • Are we motivated by fear of uncertainty, compelling us to assert our opinions as absolute truth?
